newsitem.title: USA: American, pilots talk as strike deadline looms.
newsitem.headline: American, pilots talk as strike deadline looms.

text.p: American Airlines' pilots' union said on Thursday it would present a broad offer aimed at averting a strike, but the mediator shuttling between the union and company officials said talks were slow and difficult.

With time running out before a midnight Friday (0500 GMT Saturday) strike deadline, the nation's second-largest carrier and its pilots' union continued marathon negotiations with a government mediator on hand.
"This afternoon we will make a complete proposal on competitive costs, either face-to-face or through the mediator," Allied Pilots Association President James Sovich told a news conference.
American said it would not comment on the new offer until it saw the details.

A strike would disrupt plans for hundreds of thousands of travelers. The Fort Worth, Texas-based airline is trying to rebook passengers on other carriers and has already cancelled nearly all international flights scheduled for Friday night.
A Transportation Department official said a strike could cost the U.S. economy up to $200 million a day.
The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the figure was contained in a government report sent to the National Mediation Board and the White House.

At the negotiations, the union said its proposal dealt with two of the key disputes with American -- pay for pilots on American's regular flights and whether its union pilots should fly smaller jets for the airline's American Eagle unit and their level of pay.

American wants to use lower-paid pilots from another union on the American Eagle regional flights, which the Allied Pilots Association opposes. The airline, a unit of AMR Corp., wants lower costs to compete with other major airlines' regional commuter services.
The pilots said a possible compromise would be for members of their union to fly regional jets, but at lower pay.

The union's chief negotiator, Brian Mayhew, said the pilots also offered a new proposal on pay -- presumably less than the 11.5 percent pay increase over four years sought earlier -- but he gave no details.
The latest offer on pay from American was a 6 percent raise over four years.
The union said the two sides were not that far apart and said American could afford to bridge the gap without losing its competitive position in the industry.
But the government mediator trying to bring the two sides together played down prospects for a breakthrough in the bitter dispute.

"I would characterise the pace (of the negotiations) as going still very slowly and with great difficulty. However, we are hopeful that this comprehensive proposal (from the union) will provide a means for resolution," said the National Mediation Board's Kenneth Hipp.
Separately, American Airlines Chairman Robert Crandall called for binding government arbitration of the dispute, a proposal the pilots have repeatedly rejected.
"I think mandatory binding arbitration should be required" to prevent airline strikes, Crandall told a congressional subcommittee.
"I seriously doubt we could accept that," union spokesman Wally Pitts said.
The two sides were already negotiating with a mediator present but binding arbitration would mean both parties agreed to abide by the decision of an arbitrator.
Crandall told a hearing of a House of Representatives Transportation subcommittee he was unsure if a strike could be avoided.
"We have two choices: we can either cave in or take a strike. A strike of 90 days will destroy this airline," he said.
As the talks entered their fourth day of intensive bargaining, President Bill Clinton was keeping a close watch.

Clinton could intervene and name an emergency board to try to resolve the issues. Creation of a board would prevent any work stoppages for 60 days while the board and the two parties again tried to mend their differences.
But at an unrelated news conference on Thursday, Clinton repeated that the parties should use the government mediator to reach an agreement.

"It cannot be a good thing for the people of the United States, and indeed people coming to the United States from other parts of the world, for a significant interruption to occur in the operations of this airline," he said.
